design_intent.player_goal: Build a risk-driven security program: identify risks, assess and analyze them, choose treatments, track them, and avoid privacy landmines.

trap_list.name: Threat vs Vulnerability
trap_list.misconception: A threat and a vulnerability are the same thing.
trap_list.fix: Threat = something that could cause harm; Vulnerability = a weakness. Risk is the intersection of the two.

trap_list.name: Likelihood vs Impact
trap_list.misconception: High likelihood automatically means high severity.
trap_list.fix: Severity combines likelihood (probability) AND impact (magnitude). A frequent but low-impact event may be lower priority than a rare catastrophe.

trap_list.name: ARO vs Probability
trap_list.misconception: ARO is a percentage chance like probability.
trap_list.fix: ARO is the expected frequency per year (e.g., 0.5 times/year). Probability/likelihood can be expressed in different ways, but ARO is a yearly rate for ALE math.

trap_list.name: Exposure Factor Isn’t Likelihood
trap_list.misconception: Exposure factor is how likely the event is to occur.
trap_list.fix: EF is how much of the asset is lost when the event happens (a damage percentage). Likelihood/probability/ARO are about how often it happens.

trap_list.name: SLE vs ALE
trap_list.fix: SLE = loss per event; ALE = expected loss per year (SLE×ARO).

trap_list.name: Risk Acceptance vs Neglect
trap_list.misconception: Risk acceptance means doing nothing because you’re busy.
trap_list.fix: Acceptance is a deliberate, analyzed decision. Neglect is unmanaged risk. Document acceptance, including exceptions/exemptions when applicable.

trap_list.name: Appetite vs Tolerance vs Threshold
trap_list.misconception: Appetite, tolerance, and threshold are synonyms.
trap_list.fix: Appetite = broad willingness to accept risk; Tolerance = capacity to withstand; Threshold = boundary/trigger that demands action.

trap_list.name: RTO vs RPO (and MTTR)
trap_list.misconception: RTO and RPO both mean 'how fast to recover'.
trap_list.fix: RTO = max downtime; RPO = max data loss (time). MTTR is average repair time and must typically be <= RTO.

trap_list.name: Controller vs Processor vs Custodian
trap_list.misconception: The party holding the data is always the controller.
trap_list.fix: Controller decides purpose/means; Processor acts for the controller; Custodian safeguards data without controller authority.

trap_list.name: Hashing Isn’t Magic Anonymization
trap_list.misconception: Hashed data can’t be reversed, so it’s always anonymous.
trap_list.fix: Hashes can be matched via rainbow tables or brute-force when inputs are guessable. Use salting, tokenization, masking, or stronger privacy techniques as appropriate.

missions.name: Risk Basics & Identification
missions.goal: Separate threats from vulnerabilities, then find the real risks hiding in systems, vendors, and legacy tech.

missions.name: Assess & Analyze
missions.goal: Turn messy uncertainty into priorities using assessment types and qualitative vs quantitative analysis.

mechanics.twist: Math traps: EF vs ARO vs probability.

missions.name: Treat the Risk
missions.goal: Pick the right strategy—mitigate, avoid, transfer, accept—and track what’s left.

mechanics.twist: Acceptance must be deliberate, not neglect.

missions.name: Register & Report
missions.goal: Build a usable risk register and deliver reporting that executives can actually read.

missions.name: DRP & BIA Essentials
missions.goal: Plan recovery like you mean it: know what breaks business, what must come back first, and what metrics rule the timeline.

missions.name: Privacy & Data Roles
missions.goal: Inventory data, classify it, and know who is responsible for what under privacy frameworks.

mechanics.twist: Controller vs processor mix-ups trigger traps.

missions.name: Lifecycle, PETs & Notifications
missions.goal: Minimize data, limit purpose, retain correctly, destroy safely, and survive breach notifications across jurisdictions.

boss.name: Boss: The Risk Register from Hell
boss.premise: A leadership team wants numbers, a regulator wants notifications, and IT wants to keep the legacy system. Build a defensible risk posture: quantify losses, pick treatments, write the register, and avoid privacy violations.

mechanics.phase_1: Identify the real risk (threat+vulnerability) and categorize internal/external/multiparty sources.
mechanics.phase_2: Run qualitative + quantitative analysis (SLE/ALE), then choose a treatment strategy aligned to appetite/tolerance/threshold.
mechanics.phase_3: Finalize risk register fields (owner/KRIs/threshold) and handle privacy roles and breach notification decisions with counsel.

constraint_cards.name: Executive Attention Span
constraint_cards.effect: Dashboards and heat maps are weighted; verbose register-only thinking is penalized.

constraint_cards.name: Budget Ceiling
constraint_cards.effect: Transference and acceptance questions appear more often; justify decisions with appetite/tolerance/threshold.

constraint_cards.name: Multi-Jurisdiction Chaos
constraint_cards.effect: Privacy and notification obligations appear more often; consult-counsel cues are rewarded.

modes.name: Risk Duel
modes.description: Rapid-fire: identify the best risk treatment or privacy role for a scenario.

rules.scoring: Correct + speed bonus; wrong triggers a trap card.

fairness.anti_cheat: Server-side timing and randomized option order; replay detection for identical patterns.
